results.name: The binary Champernowne sequence: concatenate binary vectors of lengths 1, 2, 3, ... in numerical order.
comment: Can also be seen as triangle where row n contains all binary vectors of length n+1. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 18 2015
reference: Bodil Branner, Dynamics, Chap. IV.14 of The Princeton Companion to Mathematics, ed. T. Gowers, p. 499.
K. Dajani and C. Kraaikamp, Ergodic Theory of Numbers, Math. Assoc. America, 2002, p. 72.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Michael Barnsley, and Andrew Vince, Self-similar polygonal tiling, The American Mathematical Monthly 124.10 (2017): 905-921. See page 917.
Igor Pak, Complexity problems in enumerative combinatorics, arXiv:1803.06636 [math.CO], 2018.
formula: To get the m-th binary vector, write m+1 in base 2 and remove the initial 1. - _Clark Kimberling_, Feb 07 2010
program: a076478_list = concat $ tail $ map (tail . reverse . unfoldr
(\x -> if x == 0 then Nothing else Just $ swap $ divMod x 2 )) [1..]
a076478_tabf = tail $ iterate (\bs -> map (0 :) bs ++ map (1 :) bs) [[]]
